Project Description  The  Chongqing–Lichuan  Railway  (CLR)  Development  Project  is  a 
priority  project  included  in  the  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (11FYP)  of  the 
Government  of  the  PRC  (Government).  The  Project  is  located  in  the 
central  part  of  Chongqing  municipality  and  the  northwestern  part  of 
Hubei  province,  a  relatively  poor  area,  and  is  designed  to  promote 
sustainable  economic  growth  by  constructing  259  kilometers  (km)  of 
railway  line  from  Chongqing  to  Lichuan  in  Hubei  province.  The  Project 
will  (i)  develop  an  efficient,  safe,  affordable,  and  environmentally 
sustainable  railway  transport  system  in  the  region;  and  (ii)  help  create 
more employment and income-generating opportunities, thus benefiting 
poor residents.  
 
The  Project  reflects  ADB’s  railway  sector  operational  strategy  for  the 
PRC,  which  includes  reducing  railway  network  constraints  to  promote 
sustainable economic growth in poor areas not served by railways. The 
components have been formulated in line with the Ministry of Railway’s 
(MOR’s) 2004 railway development plan and its 11FYP (2006–2010). 
 
CLR  is  in  line  with  the  Government’s  western  development  strategy  to 
provide  less-developed  regions  with  better  infrastructure  to  facilitate 
economic  growth,  thereby  giving  people  more  opportunities  to  improve 
their living standards. The interior regions of the PRC have not benefited 
as  much  from  economic  growth  and  reforms  as  the  east  coast;  in  fact, 
the  gap  between  economic  and  social  development  has  increased.

CLR,  a  joint-venture  railway  between  the  MOR  and  the  Chongqing 
municipal  government,  will  have  substantial  managerial  and  financial 
autonomy.  The  Project  will  help  change  railway  enterprises  from  cost 
centers  in  a  planned  economy  to  profit  centers  in  an  increasingly 
competitive transport market.  
 
The Project will help increase standards of living and reduce poverty in 
the  project  area  by  removing  a  transport  constraint  on  sustainable 
economic growth, and improve safety and reliability by introducing new 
and  modern  technology.  This  will  be  achieved  through  the  provision  of 
efficient,  affordable,  environment-friendly,  and  energy-efficient  railway 
transportation in unserved, less developed areas, creating the conditions 
necessary  for  developing  local  resources  and  generating  employment 
and income-enhancing opportunities. 
 
Project preparation was participatory. Extensive consultations were held 
with  all  the  main  stakeholders—various  affected  people,  potential 
beneficiaries,  village  leaders,  women’s  groups,  local  ethnic  minority 
bureaus, and local governments in the project area. Household surveys 
were  carried  out  and  participatory  workshops  were  organized  in  the 
project area to elicit and gain an understanding of public opinion about 
the  Project  and  provide  inputs  to  the  social  and  environmental 
assessments. 
 
The  Project  comprises  (i)  the  construction  of  259  km  of  double-track, 
electrified,  standard-gauge  Class  I  railway  from  Chongqing  to  Lichuan; 
(ii) the construction of eight new railway stations complete with facilities; 
(iii) safety  initiatives,  including  the  provision  of  modern  technology  and 
the  provision  of  signaling, 
equipment 
communication,  and  management  information  systems;  (v)  training  in 
the use and maintenance of modern equipment; (vi) consulting services 
for  construction  supervision,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  marketing 
and business development; and (vii) institutional strengthening. The key 
inputs  needed  for  project  implementation  are  civil  works,  equipment, 
consultants, and MOR and project company staff.

The Project will benefit about 5.5 million people living in the project area. 
The poverty and social assessment looked at seven counties or districts. 
Two  counties  are  designated  national  or  provincial  poverty  counties. 
There  are  681  poverty  villages  and  about  590,000  people  are  poor. 
About 65% of the beneficiaries live in rural areas, and 16.4% are poor, 
with  an  annual  net  income  per  capita  of  less  than  CNY900.  The  links 
between  poverty,  difficult  topography,  and  poor  transport  systems  are 
apparent  in  the  project  area  for  the  proposed  CLR.  Poverty  is  often 
caused  by  geographic  remoteness  and  isolation,  limited  transport 
access, high transport costs, and poor access to market information, as 
well as limited access to health, education, and other social services. 
 
The  Project  will  facilitate  the  creation  of  additional  employment  and 
income-generating  opportunities.  About  119,000  person-years  of  work 
will  be created  during  construction. This  will  provide  direct employment 
opportunities  to  over  59,500  poor  people,  including  women  and  ethnic 
minorities.  Railway  station  area  development  will  increase  incomes  in 
local  communities  and  help  generate  local  revenues.  The  Project  will 
facilitate  the  development  of  small  businesses,  local  industry,  and 
tourism, and thus help generate additional opportunities in the future for 
local  people.  Consultations  with  local  people  in  the  project  area 
indicated their strong support for the Project. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  and  economically  sustainable.  The  5.48% 
financial  internal  rate  of  return  exceeds  the  2.80%  weighted  average 
cost  of  capital.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is  estimated  at 
16.7%.  
 
The  increased  tax  revenues  generated  by  the  economic  development 
induced by the Project will help finance improved social service facilities 
and basic infrastructure.

risks  have  been  assessed  and  mitigating  measures  based  on  lessons 
learned from other railroad projects in the PRC have been provided.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, to 2007, the PRC 
experienced  sustained  rapid  economic  growth,  which  resulted  in  a  correspondingly  rapid 
increase  in  demand  for  transportation.  Passenger  transport  grew  by  9%  yearly  and  freight 
transport by 7.6%. The railway is the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC. In 2006, the 
modal split for freight ton-kilometers (km) was 47.5% for railways, 27.9% for inland waterways 
and sea-to-shore shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. That 
same year, road traffic accounted for 52.8% of total passenger-kilometers, railways for 34.5%, 
civil aviation for 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways for 0.4%.  
 
3. 
The railway is the primary mode of transport for long-distance and bulk transport. At the 
end of 2007, the PRC’s railway system of 78,000 km comprised 63,600 km of national railways 
and 14,400 km of joint-venture and local railways. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) operates the 
state-owned  national  railway  as  an  integrated  system.  The  joint-venture  and  local  railways, 
comprising regional lines within provincial boundaries, are constructed under the sponsorship of 
provincial governments or MOR to serve local needs and provide interconnection to the national 
railway  network.  The  railway  network,  despite  its  large  size,  does  not  adequately  cover  the 
country’s population and land area.1

second-highest passenger transport density after Japan’s. Locomotive turnover is the highest in 
the world. From 1978 to 2007, railway freight increased yearly by 5.28%, from 535 billion ton-km 
to  2,380 billion ton-km,  and  passenger  traffic  by  6.74%,  from  109 billion  passenger-km  to 
722 billion passenger-km. For passenger trips, the average railway journey increased from 134 
km in 1978 to 532 km in 2007; in comparison, the average road journey lengthened from 35 km 
to 55 km over the same period. For freight, the average journey in 2007 was 757 km for railway 
and  65  km  for  road.  Despite  such  growth  rates,  railway  capacity  has  lagged  behind  demand 
because  of  system  constraints  (Appendix  2).  Given  the  railways’  important  role  in  providing 
economic  transportation,  these  constraints,  if  not  removed,  will  continue  to  thwart  efficient 
economic  growth.  The  Government’s  aggressive  plan  for  improving  railways  includes  network 
expansion and construction in underserved areas.

6. 
In 2004, the State Council approved a new railway development plan for the period up to 
2020. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 100,000 km. Increasing train speed is a 
major goal. Priority will be given to developing railways in unserved areas and regions that now 
lack transport and are still less developed. The route network length will increase by 16,000 km 
in the western region of the PRC, to reach a network length of 40,000 km by 2020. To improve

corridors.2

The  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (11FYP)  (2006–2010)  continues  to  emphasize  railway 
development,  and  seeks  to  speed  up  railway  construction.  The  plan  envisages  (i)  the 
construction of 17,000 km of new lines, and (ii) the double-tracking and electrification of 45% of 
the network length. The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger railway network through 
the construction of 7,000 km of passenger dedicated lines by 2010; (ii) develop coal transport 
corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway network in the 
poor  western  region  (to  34,000  km);  (iv)  build  international  corridors  at  the  southwest  and 
northwest  borders;  and  (v)  develop  a  nationwide  intermodal  container  network.  A  total 
investment  of  CNY1.5  trillion—CNY1.25  trillion  for  construction  and  CNY250  billion  for  rolling 
stock—is  planned  in  the  11FYP,  of  which  a  total  of  CNY465.2  billion  has  been  spent  in  2006 
and 2007 (Appendix 3).

Asian Development Bank Strategy and Sector Experience 

 
8. 
The  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  the  railway  sector  involves 
helping  (i) expand  the  railway  system  by  constructing  new  lines  in  unserved,  less-developed 
areas; (ii) modernize railways, enhance safety, and increase the capacity to improve efficiency 
on  key  routes  of  the  national  railway  system;  (iii)  commercialize  railway  operations  to  sustain 
efficient  operations;  (iv)  promote  energy  conservation  and  environmental  sustainability;  and 
(v) increase railway competitiveness in the transport sector through restructuring and reform. At 
the heart of the strategy is the development of railways in poor, less-developed inland provinces 
to  promote  sustainable  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty. 3 ADB  has  provided  15  loans 
totaling  over  $3.0  billion  to  finance  the  construction  of  about  1,921  km  of  eight  provincial 
railways  operated  by  joint  ventures  with  MOR,  and  5,541  km  of  new  railway  lines  under  six 
national railway projects, and a sector-wide intervention to improve safety on the PRC railway 
network. ADB assistance to the sector has evolved from financing civil works on local railways 
to  supporting  major  national  corridors  with  much  less  financing  but  with  safety,  management 
information  system,  environmental,  and  other  technological  improvements  (Appendix  4).  The 
Project,  designed  to  promote  economic  growth  by  providing  safe  and  reliable  railway 
transportation  in  unserved,  less-developed,  and  poor  areas  of  Chongqing  municipality  and 
Hubei province, is consistent with the PRC’s development priorities and the ADB strategy.

international  practices  worldwide,  (ii)  separate  core  operations  from  noncore  transportation

10.  MOR  is  taking  a  structured  approach  to  railway  reform.  In  1999,  using  a  new 
management  concept—the  asset  operating  liability  system—it  entered  into  management 
contracts with railway administrations to improve profitability (as a pilot project). The contracts 
helped  improve  operational  and  financial  performance;  this  approach  was  subsequently 
extended to all railway administrations. The separation of core and noncore businesses is a key 
element  of  MOR’s  restructuring  program.  The  total  number  of  employees  in  the  core 
transportation  business  was  reduced  from  1.89  million  in  1997  to  1.41  million  in  2006.  In  the 
noncore  transportation  business,  five  large  companies  employing  616,500  staff  have  been 
divested.  To  provide  jobs  for  redundant  staff,  by  the  end  of  2006  MOR  had  set  up 
3,625 diversified businesses (independent of the core transportation business) employing more 
than  321,544  staff  to  supply  equipment,  goods,  and  services  to  the  railway  industry.  In  1998, 
MOR initiated a cost-sharing scheme for health insurance and pensions for railway employees. 
In 2005, it completed the transfer of 822 primary and middle schools, 46 vocational schools, and 
181 nursery schools, and 260 hospitals and medical units to local governments. One hundred 
branch lines comprising 7,800 km were separated to improve productivity and reduce operating 
losses.  (The  reform  agenda  matrix  is  in  Appendix  5.  Supplementary  Appendix  A  contains  a

Enhancing  Safety. Safety is an integral part of a competitive, high-quality, and reliable 
transportation system for people and goods. As PRC railways have modernized, introduced new 
concepts  and  technologies,  and  increased  speeds,  the  safety  needs  have  changed.  MOR’s 
11FYP recognizes this important aspect and seeks to attract foreign technology and know-how 
to meet these needs. ADB, for its part, emphasizes in its policy dialogue with MOR the need for 
operational  reforms  for  the  rail  network,  including  safety  improvements  in  construction, 
operation,  and  maintenance.  MOR  and  ADB  support  the  objective  of  safety  and  security  on 
PRC railways through the introduction of modern technologies, policy development, legislation, 
monitoring  and  enforcement,  and  outreach  activities  (Appendix  6).  Since  2003,  ADB  has 
supported investments in railway safety as part of ADB financing. ADB has initiated dialogue on 
adopting a sector-wide approach, rather than a project-based approach, to safety. A sector-wide 
approach is consistent with the network approach adopted for train operations in the PRC and 
helps  in  providing  economies  of  scale,  and  better  management  of  emergencies,  preventive 
maintenance,  and  accidents.  ADB  has  worked  closely  with  the  safety  and  transportation 
departments  of  MOR  to  develop  a  comprehensive  plan  for  the  institutional,  investment,  and 
training  needs  for  safety  in  PRC  railways  and  is  providing  a  TA  grant  of  $500,000  to  help  in 
developing an emergency management system.7 In 2007, ADB approved a $100 million loan for 
enhancing safety on the PRC railway network.8

the  structure  of  transport  demand  is  likely  to  change.12 An  ADB  advisory  TA  for  policy  reform

4. 

Rationale 

22. 
The  project  rationale  reflects  (i)  network  development;  (ii) capacity  enhancement; 
(iii) safety  enhancement;  (iv) support  for  the  PRC  railway  development  plan  and  the  western 
region development strategy; and (v) promotion of pro-poor economic growth along the railway 
line and in the region, thereby reducing poverty. The Project will pursue the operational reforms, 
including  emphasis  on  safety  and  the  introduction  of  safe  and  reliable  technology,  faster 
speeds,  double-stack  container  operation  under  an  electrified  line,  modern  dispatch  control 
systems, and high-quality information systems on the railway network. 
 
23. 
The proposed CLR is part of the shortest east–west corridor linking Shanghai, Qingdao, 
Wuhan, Yichang, and other major cities and ports in the east to Chongqing and Chengdu in the 
west.  The  proposed  alignment  for  the  CLR  is  369  km  shorter  than  the  existing  route  between 
Shanghai and Chengdu. Traversing Hubei province, and Chongqing municipality, the proposed 
railway  line  will  connect  with  Shanghai–Wuhan–Yichang–Lichuan  in  the  east,  Chongqing–
Huaihua railway in the center, the proposed Lanzhou–Chongqing24 and Xi’an–Chongqing main 
lines in the north, Chongqing–Chengdu in the west, and Chongqing–Kunming in the south. 
 
24. 
The  project area  for  Chongqing–Lichuan  is  largely  mountainous,  with  abundant  natural 
reserves  of  coal,  natural  gas,  nonferrous  materials,  and  famous  tourist  sites.  But  despite  the 
abundant  natural  resources,  many  people  are  poor  and  the  economic  growth  necessary  to 
reduce rural poverty has failed to materialize because of inadequate transport services and high 
costs.  Local  governments  and  people  living  in  the  project  area  see  the  railway  as  a  key 
investment  for  addressing  this  problem.  The  development  of  the  railway  line  and  associated 
developments are expected to stimulate industrial and natural resources development, promote 
tourism and related industries, generate employment and increase living standards, and help to 
reduce  poverty.  The  Project  is  a  part  of  the  Government’s  program  for  the  integrated 
development  of  transportation  facilities,  which  includes  the  project  railway,  the  upgrading  of 
highways, and the construction of link and access roads to the hinterland. Other infrastructure, 
such  as  water  supply  and  investment  to  improve  education  and  health  care  facilities,  are  also 
planned. The railway will play an important role in facilitating the development and integration of 
this poor and underdeveloped region. 
 
CLR  will  be  a  joint-venture  railway  owned  and  operated  by  MOR  and  the  Chongqing 
25. 
municipal  government.  Joint-venture  railways,  which  account  for  9,517  km  (2007)  of  the  PRC 
system,  have  substantial  managerial  and  financial  autonomy,  including  the  freedom  to  set 
tariffs, which are several times higher than those of the national network. Freight and passenger 
traffic on joint-venture railways have grown faster than on national railways. Between 1996 and 
2007, passenger traffic grew from 2.2 billon passenger-km to 31.5 billion passenger-km (or by 
28%  yearly,  compared  with  7%  on  the  national  railway  network),  and  freight  traffic  rose  from 
12.3  billion  ton-km  to  155.2  billion  ton-km  (or  by  26.5%  yearly,  compared  with  5%  on  the 
national railway network). Joint-venture railways are more efficient, employing only 8–10 people 
per km, compared with about 25 people per km for national railways. The project company will 
employ 8–10 people per km.

The Project is a key intervention in the railway sector, with many technical, operational,

significantly  compared  to  existing  bus  and  truck  fares  thereby  providing  a  cheaper  and  more 
affordable mode of transport. ADB financing is playing a catalytic role in financing this project. 
CLR will introduce double-stack container operation, under an electrified track. This will increase 
the  throughput  and  carrying  capacity,  reduce  the  land  requirement,  and  reduce  the  energy 
consumption and emission per ton-km—all of which will lead to a more affordable, faster, cheap, 
safe, energy-efficient, and more environment-friendly mode of transport in the region. Running 
conventional trains and double-stack container trains under a common track is a technological 
challenge  that  will  need  higher  axle-loads,  adjusted  tunnel  and  bridge  dimensions,  and  new 
technologies for power transfer from overhead electric traction to adapt to the increased height 
difference between conventional trains and the double-stack container trains. A corporate entity 
has been set up to construct, operate, and manage the CLR, and that it will help enhance the 
financial viability and private sector participation. ADB is assisting in institutional, marketing, and 
business development for the project company. The agreed tariffs are affordable and financially 
viable. When complete, the Project will provide a shorter link to the west, releasing capacity on 
the existing railway lines.

53. 
The  project  benefits  and  impact  have  been  assessed,  along  with  the  potential  risks

A. 

Traffic Forecast 

54. 
The  traffic  forecast  is  based  on  forecasts  prepared  by  the  Second  Survey  and  Design 
Institute  and  the  assessment  of  TA  consultants  after  considering  expected  economic  growth, 
population  increase,  tourism  development  potential, local government  development  plans,  and 
market  surveys.  The  passenger  volume  on  the  CLR  is  forecast  to  grow  from  8.38 billion 
passenger-km  in  2014  to  25.78  billion  passenger-km  in  2033,  for  an  average  growth  rate  of 
6.4% yearly. The freight traffic on the CLR corridor is forecast, on the basis of similar factors, to 
increase  from  about  7.16 billion  ton-km  in  2014  to  20.13  billion  ton-km  in  2033,  or  by  5.9% 
yearly.  The  projected  volumes  can  be  accommodated  by  the  CLR  and  justify  project 
construction. 
 
B. 

Economic Benefits 

55. 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated through a comparison of the 
with- and without-project situations, using constant 2008 economic prices. The CLR will reduce 
the  cost  of  transport  to  and  from  the  poor  parts  of  Chongqing  and  Hubei  province.  The 
economic  costs  include  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  costs,  and  the  value  of 
agricultural production from land lost permanently. The economic benefits include (i) operating 
cost  savings  for  freight  and  passenger  traffic;  (ii)  time  saved  as  a  result  of  the  diversion  of 
passenger  traffic  from  buses  trucks,  and  other  rail  lines;  (iii)  transport  benefits  generated; 
(iv) tourism benefits; (v) road infrastructure and maintenance costs avoided; (vi) shipper savings 
resulting  from  increased  railway  competition;  (vii)  road  accidents  avoided;  (viii)  reduced 
pollution; (ix) energy savings; and (x) national productivity benefits. The project EIRR is 16.7%, 
indicating that the Project is economically viable (Appendix 14). Sensitivity analysis confirms the 
robustness  of  the  Project’s  economic  viability.  Changes  in  the  key  variables,  such  as  a  20% 
reduction  in  benefits,  do  not  significantly  affect  economic  viability.  The  civil  works  cost  would 
have to increase by 60.0% over the estimate for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. 
Freight  benefits  would  have  to  fall  by  44.0%  and  passenger  benefits  by  936.8%.  Given  the 
experience  in  the  PRC  railway  sector,  variations  of  such  magnitude  are  unlikely.  Project  risks 
were  quantified  through  the  statistical  method,  i.e.,  by  considering  the  possible  value  for  key 
variables and the probability of their occurrence. The result shows minimal probability of EIRR 
falling  below  12%.  Distribution  analysis,  undertaken  by  determining  the  project  effects  for 
various  beneficiaries,  indicates  that  a  large  portion  of  net  benefits  will  accrue  to  project  users 
and the economy.

69. 
The  Project  has  been  formulated  to  minimize  potential  risks.  In  view  of  the  experience 
with  previous  railway  projects,  traffic  demand  has  been  estimated  conservatively.  Sensitivity 
tests indicate that economic circumstances would have to become substantially adverse for the 
Project to lose economic viability. A potential risk is delay in implementation, which would delay 
the  realization  of  benefits.  MOR  has  successfully  built  railway  lines,  such  as  the  Ganzhou–
Longyan, Hefei–Xi’an, and Jing–Jiu railways. Government, MOR, CMG support for the Project

(EMP) and will be closely monitored during project implementation. 
 
70. 
Intermodal competition among railways and roads will create market risks for the project 
railway. However, the existing road is already congested and capacity constraints are expected 
to worsen. Traffic surveys indicate that the railway has several advantages: lower fares, shorter 
travel times, safety, and punctuality. The increasing commercial orientation of the joint-venture 
railway will help lower the risks posed by intermodal competition.

Recent  Developments.  To  minimize  transport  inefficiencies  and  eliminate  transport

indicates  that  total  transport  investment  should  increase  to  at  least  3.8%  of  GDP  to  avoid  the 
economic costs associated with transport constraints. The Government continues to accord high 
priority to transport infrastructure investments to meet the increase in transport demand.

TRAFFIC FORECAST AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

 

Traffic Forecast 
 
1. 
Freight  traffic  for  the  Chongqing–Lichuan  Railway  (CLR)  was  forecast  by  commodity 
(i.e.,  coal,  petroleum  products,  iron  and  steel,  fertilizers,  intermodal  containers,  and  other 
commodities) in two categories differentiated by their economic impact: (i) traffic diverted from 
other modes (other railway routes, roads, and inland waterway) based on an assessment of the 
relative  service-  and  cost-competitiveness  of  the  project  railway;  and  (ii)  generated  traffic  that 
would only move because of the existence of a railway line where none previously existed. The 
traffic  forecast  was  based  on  a  two-tier  analysis:  (i)  national  transport  demand  based  on 
historical  trends  correlating  socioeconomic  parameters,  such  as  gross  domestic  product  and 
propensity  to  travel  or  ship  or  demand  for  railway  transport;  (ii)  national  and  regional  railway 
traffic  demand  based  on  commodity-specific  analysis  for  major  commodities  currently  using 
other  railway  lines,  roads,  and  inland  waterways.
Traffic  projections  considered  expected 
economic  growth,  population  increase,  tourism  development  potential,  local  government 
development plans, market surveys, and assessments of technical assistance consultants and 
Asian Development Bank missions. The freight volume on the CLR is forecast to increase from 
about 7.16 billion ton-kilometers (ton-km) in 2014 to 20.13 billion ton-km in 2033, for an average 
annual  growth  rate  of  5.9%.
Passenger  traffic  is  forecast  to  grow  from  8.38  billion  passenger-
kilometers  (passenger-km)  in  2014  to  25.78  billion  passenger-km  in  2033,  for  an  average 
annual  growth  rate  of  6.4%  (Table  A14.1).  Traffic  forecasts  are  considered  reasonable,  given 
that (i) the CLR is an important link along the Chengdu–Chongqing–Shanghai transport corridor, 
connecting  western  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  with  the  east,  as  well  as  serving  as  a 
gateway to the PRC–Eurasian rail network for intermodal transport; (ii) railways in the PRC have 
experienced high annual traffic growth with recent rates higher than the assumed growth rates 
for  freight  and  passenger  traffic;  (iii)  the  existing  parallel  road  within  the  project  corridor  is 
congested  in  some  areas,  making  road  transport  expensive  and  hazardous;  and  (iv)  the 
distance saved by routing traffic through CLR compared with other railway lines is up to 369 km 
in  origin–destination  pairs  involving  long-distance  movement  between  eastern  and  western 
PRC.  
 
B.  

Economic Evaluation  

 

2. 
Analysis  of  Alternatives.  As  part  of  the  economic  analysis,  possible  alternative 
interventions were considered, to meet the growing transport demand in the project area as part 
of  the  national  and  provincial  transport  network  plan.  Various  options,  in  terms  of  transport 
modes,  alignments,  and  technical  designs,  were  reviewed.  While  enhancing  the  existing  road 
capacity  may  be  an  option  to  partly  meet  the  increasing  demand,  it  will  not  completely  satisfy 
the various kinds of traffic, particularly bulk cargo such as coal over long distances to meet the 
needs  of  a  growing  economy.  Aside  from  the  higher  initial  cost,  increased  land  requirements, 
high  air  pollution,  fuel  consumption,  and  user  costs  make  the  road  alternative  less  viable. 
Multiple alignment alternatives were subsequently evaluated for four line sections, considering 
geologic  and  topographic  conditions,  terrain,  the  results  of  consultations  with  community 
representatives,  cost  estimates,  relative  impact  on  the  environment  and  resettlement,  and  the 
objective of integration with the national and local transport network. The technical design was 
proposed  after  consideration  of  the  national  railway  network,  consistency  in  the  standards  of 
contiguous sections at each end of the project railway, and forecast traffic.  
 
3. 
Cost.  The  economic  evaluation  is  based  on  a  comparison  of  with-  and  without-project 
scenarios,  using  constant  2008  economic  prices.  Under  the  without-project  scenario  it  is 
assumed  that  the  diverted  traffic  (27.3  million  tons  and  26.1  million  passengers  by  2014)

4. 
Benefits.  Economic  benefits  include  (i)  user  cost  savings  for  freight  and  passenger 
traffic;  (ii)  time  savings for  diverted passenger and  freight  traffic  from  buses,  trucks,  and  other 
rail  lines;  (iii)  generated  passenger  and  freight  transport  benefits;  (iv)  tourism  benefits; 
(v) avoided  road  infrastructure  and  maintenance  costs;  (vi)  shipper  savings  due  to  increased 
railway  competition;  (vii)  avoided  road  accidents;  (viii)  pollution  reduction  benefits;  (ix)  energy 
savings; and (x) national productivity benefits.  
 
5. 
For passenger traffic diverted from road (3.38 million passengers in 2014), the user cost 
saving  (CNY53.74  million  by  2014)  is  the  difference  in  the  passenger  economic  fare  between 
road  and  rail  transport  (CNY0.0003  per  passenger-km).  For  passenger  traffic  diverted  from 
other railway lines (22.72 million passengers by 2014), the user cost savings (CNY7.78 million 
by 2014) is the difference of route distance applied to the economic cost of rail passenger travel 
(CNY0.051  per  passenger-km).  For  generated  passenger  traffic  (both  local  and  interline)  the 
passenger-km estimate (2.46 billion by 2014) is multiplied by one-half of the average economic 
cost savings (CNY0.0004 per passenger-km). Passenger traffic time savings (CNY2.21 million 
by 2014) are computed only for diverted traffic.  
 
6. 
For freight traffic diverted from trucks (6.24 million tons by 2014), the economic benefit 
(CNY272.84 million by 2014) is the difference in shipper economic costs between truck and rail 
transport  (CNY0.193  per  ton-km).  For  traffic  diverted  from  other  PRC  railways  routes  to  CLR, 
the benefit is the rail-diverted ton-km (4.84 billion by 2014) applied to the same economic rate of 
rail  transport  (CNY0.0364  per  ton-km).  For  freight  traffic  diverted  from  inland  waterways  (1.29 
million  tons  by  2014),  the  economic  benefit  (CNY0.24  million  by  2014)  is  the  difference  in 
shipper  economic  costs  between  inland  waterway  and  rail  transport  (CNY0.0007  per  ton-km). 
For generated freight traffic benefits (CNY1,425.9 million by 2014) an adjusted economic value 
added ranging from CNY565 per ton for non-containerized bulk cargo to CNY4,406 per ton for 
containerized cargo was computed on the basis of the current financial value, non-tax elements, 
shadow exchange rate factor, percentage of value added, percentage of net taxes, depreciation, 
and operating surplus for each commodity. The adjusted economic values per ton represent the 
net  economic  value,  i.e.,  the  value  of  output  at  economic  prices  less  the  costs  of  production 
(sum of all intermediate input costs, including wages, and annualized investment costs). Similar 
to passenger traffic, freight traffic time savings (CNY0.34 million by 2014) are computed only for 
diverted traffic. 
 
Tourism  benefits  (CNY74.26  million  by  2014)  assume  that  15%  of  generated  interline

8. 
The  construction  of  CLR  will  help  avoid  some  costs  that  would  not  be  possible  in  the 
absence  of  CLR.  The  economic  analysis  estimated  four  such  cases  of  cost  avoidance: 
(i) avoided  highway  investment  costs  (initial  investment  of  CNY191.21  million  by  2014,  with 
annual  incremental  investments  ranging  from  CNY6.68  million  by  2014  to  CNY9.04  million  by 
2033  to  accommodate  the  increased  traffic  every  year);  (ii)  avoided  highway  routine  and 
periodic  maintenance  costs  (CNY13.99  million  by  2014,  increasing  to  CNY31.81  million  by 
2033);  (iii)  avoided  truck  shipping  charges  to  freight  shippers  due  to  increased  competition 
brought  about  by  CLR  (CNY207.59  million  by  2014,  increasing  to  CNY524.57  by  2033);  and 
(iv) avoided road accident costs (CNY110.43 million by 2014, increasing to CNY251.11 million 
by 2033).  
 
9. 
Energy  and  pollution  benefits  have  also  been  estimated  for  the  Project.  With  the 
diversion  of  freight  and  passengers  from  road  to  rail,  there  will  be  benefits  due  to  reduced 
pollution  from  trucks,  buses,  and  cars  as  well  as  less  energy  used  by  the  transport  sector. 
Recent  research  by  the  International  Energy  Agency  was  used  as  a  basis  for  computing  the 
number  of  tons  of  carbon  dioxide  (CO2)  per  traffic  unit  for  road  and  rail  for  the  PRC.  These 
savings for rail compared with road were found to be 25.4 tons of CO2 per million passenger-km 
and  24  tons  of  CO2  per  million  ton-km.  Under  the  provisions  of  the  Kyoto  Protocol,  certified 
emission reductions are currently valued in the PRC at $16 per ton of carbon dioxide. This value 
has  been  included  in  the  benefit  stream  (CNY32.18  million  by  2014,  increasing  to  CNY96.93 
million by 2033). In addition, the savings of reduced total fuel consumption (CNY204.0 million by 
2014; CNY605.03 million by 2033) as a result of the diversion of traffic from both road and rail to 
CLR has been computed and included in the benefit stream. Unit operating costs for both road 
and rail transport have been adjusted to exclude fuel costs in order to eliminate double counting 
of this benefit.  

10. 
Conclusion. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project is 16.7% (Table 
A14.3).  Benefits  from  the  freight  traffic,  including  generated  benefits,  are  the  major  economic 
benefit  (approximately  55%),  with  passenger  benefits  contributing  about  3.3%  and  other 
benefits  making  up  the  remaining  balance.  Sensitivity  analysis  tested  10  scenarios  to  assess 
the  robustness  of  the  results  of  the  economic  analysis  (Table  A14.4).  The  initial  capital  cost 
would have to be more than 60.0% higher than estimated for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff 
rate  of  12%.  Considering  the  experience  of  Asian  Development  Bank-financed  projects  in  the 
railway  sector,  this  switching  value  is  unlikely  to  occur.  The  freight  benefits  would  have  to 
decrease  more  than  44%  to  make  the  Project  economically  nonviable.  A  1-year  delay  in 
completion does not affect economic viability. Combinations of adverse effects of benefits and 
costs were also tested. The results showed that the Project would maintain its economic viability 
under plausible scenarios of variability. 
 
11. 
The  economic  analysis  was  extended  to  quantify  project  risk  and  distribute  project  net 
benefits among stakeholders. The risk analysis considered the distribution of possible values for 
key variables, including capital costs, operation and maintenance costs, passenger traffic, and 
freight  traffic,  and  the  probability  with  which  they  may  occur.  The  results  show  that  the 
probability  of  an  EIRR  falling  below  12%  would  be  0.8%.  Distribution  analysis  examined  how 
project  net  benefits  would  be  distributed  by  determining  the  project  effects  for  project 
beneficiaries, such as passengers, freight shippers, labor, government, and the economy (Table 
A14.2).  At  62.3%  freight  shippers  would  be  the largest  beneficiary  group,  followed  by  national 
and local economy at 17.0%, national and local government at 15.2%, passengers at 3.9%, and 
labor at 1.6%.

inflation rates.

Following  are  the  major  assumptions  used  for  calculation  of  a  financial  internal  rate  of

railway,  but  exclude  price  contingencies  and  interest  during  construction;  (iii)  operating  costs 
include  all  annual  incremental  expenses  incurred  in  operating  the  project  railway,  but  exclude 
depreciation and debt repayment provisions; (iv) the residual value equal to one-half of the net 
book value of capital investment.

calculated  using  estimated  capital  mix  and  cost  of  funds.  Costs  have  been  considered  as 
follows: (i) the applicable 5-year London interbank offered rate fixed swap rate plus a provision 
for  ADB’s  spread  of  0.2%  is  used  for  ADB  debt;  (ii)  the  estimated  interest  rate  of  6.6%  per 
annum is used for the CCB loan; and (iii) the opportunity cost of equity capital was assumed to 
be 8%. The cost of debt is also adjusted to reflect the impact of income tax of 33%. The nominal 
cost is converted to the real cost by applying domestic and international long-term inflation rates

What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
Many  villages  located  toward  the  eastern  half  of  the  alignment  have  been  relatively  isolated  from  these  developments, 
and these are  where the very poor live. The links between poverty, topography, and transport systems are apparent in 
the project impact area. The main causes of poverty in the project areas are (i) natural calamity, (ii) lack of infrastructure, 
(iii)  very  limited  and  unsustainable  source  of  livelihood,  (vi)  uneven  economic  development,  and  (v)  poor  health.  The 
Project  will benefit about 5.5 million people in the project area; 3.6 million are in the countryside, and 590,000 of these 
(16.4%)  are  poor.  There  are  681  designated  poverty  villages  in  the  project  impact  area—31.6%  of  all  villages  in  the 
area—and they are largely concentrated in the four poorest counties. About 14% of the people in the project impact area 
are  ethnic  minorities,  almost  all  of  them  living  in  the  Shizhu–Tujia  Autonomous  County  and  the  neighboring  Lichuan 
county. 
 
About 119,000 unskilled person-years of work will be created during the construction of the railway. Half of the unskilled 
work, with total wages of CNY0.89 billion, will be targeted at the poor. Priority will be given to women, people affected by 
resettlement, ethnic minorities, and other vulnerable people. In addition, during the construction, 44,142 person-years of 
local unskilled jobs in the provision of construction materials will be created, with total wages of CNY0.4 billion; half of this 
total will be targeted at the poor. When the new railway starts to operate in 2014, about 3,530 jobs involving working for 
Chongqing–Lichuan  Railway  will  be  created.  The  local  governments  are  responsible  for  providing  social  services  and 
poverty  reduction  funds  for  county  poverty  alleviation  planning;  their  programs  will  be  augmented  by  the  railway 
construction tax revenues.  
 
The  Project’s  railway  stations  will  create  various  jobs,  and  help  distribute  the  benefits  to  local  people.  There  will  be 
sufficient  space  in  and  around  the  stations  for  local  area  development,  and  the  poor,  women,  ethnic  groups,  and  other 
vulnerable people will be supported by local governments in setting up shop and selling local specialties and other goods 
and services. The jobs created by the generated freight will total 34,909 jobs by 2014. Increased tourism will result in the

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
During  project  preparation,  analyses  of  gender-disaggregated  data  and  discussions  with  representatives  of  the  ACWF 
indicated that women will need some assistance to fully benefit from the Project. Data collected for the poverty and social 
assessment  and  the  resettlement  plan  indicate  the  following:  (i)  women  primarily  engage  in  agricultural  activities;  and 
(ii) male  members  from  poor  households  tend  to  travel  farther  for  migrant  labor  opportunities  than  non-poor  males, 
leaving  behind  a  high  percentage  of  households  headed  by  women.  The  construction  of  the  railway  would  create

women  employees.  The  ACWF  will  provide  business  management  and  financial  assistance  to  women  interested  in 
setting up small businesses that serve the construction crews and the growing tourist sector.  In addition, as women will 
have  a  greater  exposure  to  the  risk  of  HIV/AIDS/STIs  and  human  trafficking,  the  mitigation  measures  will  pay  special 
attention to women.  
 
Poverty  and  social  enhancement  measures  have  been  built  into  the  project  design,  and  special  mitigation  or

as  schools  provide  an  informal  source  of  day  care  for  their  children.  Poor  women  heads  of  households  will  receive 
assistance so that their children can remain in school, freeing the women’s time during the day to work.  Widows will be 
eligible  for  special  assistance,  if  necessary,  during  land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  Women  will  be  given  priority  in 
project-generated employment during the construction and operation of the railway. The rise in female participation in the 
labor force and tourism market will increase women’s net income, thus improving family welfare, and raising the status of 
women.

The resettlement plan stipulates eligibility and entitlement provisions for affected people. 
Permanent land losses will be compensated by cash payments. Each rural village will use the 
land  compensation  and  resettlement  subsidy  for  income  restoration.  The  main  strategies  for 
income restoration include improvement of irrigation systems, development of animal husbandry 
and cash crops, small-business development, and migration to urban centers for employment. 
Compensation for temporary land loss will be paid directly to the people affected to offset any 
income  loss;  the  land  will  also  be  restored  by  the  contractor  to  its  original  state  after  use. 
Compensation  for  rural  housing  losses  will  be  paid  directly  to  those  affected  at  replacement 
cost,  free  of  demolition  expenses  and  salvaged  materials.  The  displaced  rural  houses  will  be 
rebuilt within the existing village or integrated with the suburban development plan. Better road 
access and provision of site leveling, water supply, electricity, telephone, and cable facilities will 
be provided. Urban households, factories, schools and other institutions, and enterprises will be 
paid compensation for relocation and reconstruction based on market rates determined through 
negotiations.  Urban  households  can  select  new  housing,  which  is  widely  available.  Most 
factories  will  only  suffer  partial  impact  and  continue  operations  at  the  same  site.  For  factories 
required to relocate, each owner will prepare a relocation plan, which includes the restoration of 
livelihood and incomes for all workers. Schools and other institutions will be rebuilt according to 
the plans of local government, to ensure that service levels are maintained or improved.
